description:
Bran remains quiet a long while, perhaps thinking it over. “I wanted to understand,” he says. “What you were. How you felt. Who he was to you.”

And Jon’s anger only worsens. Rightly or wrongly, he feels used. “And do you, now?”

reblog.comment:

trail.content_raw:
Bran remains quiet a long while, perhaps thinking it over. “I wanted to understand,” he says. “What you were. How you felt. Who he was to you.”

And Jon’s anger only worsens. Rightly or wrongly, he feels used. “And do you, now?”
trail.content:
Bran remains quiet a long while, perhaps thinking it over. “I wanted to understand,” he says. “What you were. How you felt. Who he was to you.”

And Jon’s anger only worsens. Rightly or wrongly, he feels used. “And do you, now?”

summary: You know what bothers me is the fact the there are Jaime fans who also like Sansa and therefore want them to be best buddies. He...
question: You know what bothers me is the fact the there are Jaime fans who also like Sansa and therefore want them to be best buddies. He tried to murder her brother and had no problem working against the rest of her family, with his family, trying to kill them, why would they get along in any capacity? I feel like it comes from these Jaime fans who woobify him and are desperate for him to get redemption. People especially women are far nicer to Jaime, who is a terrible person, than they are to Cersei.
answer: Forget Sansa, Bran! People think Bran will laugh off his almost death and all the horror that came after it. I bet many people sighed in relief when D&D decided to retcon Bran’s characterisation so that Jon can keep being king and so that Jaime doesn’t have to face one of his victims.

reblog.comment: Forget Sansa, Bran! People think Bran will laugh off his almost death and all the horror that came after it. I bet many people sighed in relief when D&D decided to retcon Bran’s characterisation so that Jon can keep being king and so that Jaime doesn’t have to face one of his victims.

I bet many people sighed in relief when D&D decided to retcon Bran’s characterisation so that Jon can keep being king and so that Jaime doesn’t have to face one of his victims.

tags: how many sf/f references can i stick into one meta
everyone's got grand hopes for their faves in twow and i keep wanting to yell 'no that's ados' sigh
summary: Can it be argued that Bran has yet to learn the "comes great responsibility" part of the "with great power comes great...
question: Can it be argued that Bran has yet to learn the "comes great responsibility" part of the "with great power comes great responsibility" process? You've detailed the creeeeeepy warging of Hodor that Bran has done, and I am wondering if terrible events to come will have him reeling away from his powers? Maybe Euron tempts Bran, via docking mentally with him (like when he saw Varamyr) and he's like "Go further... let the hate flow through you" or something like that. Just my crazy thought process!
answer:
It’s not that crazy, no worries. And yeah, I’ve said before that TWOW is going to be the dark night of the soul for most of the POV characters… and Bran is definitely no exception. Hodor will be a major issue, the climax of that probably coming near the end of the book… as well as Bran losing himself in the past out of a need to see more, to know, to fly… which, if the show is not completely fanfic here, will also climax in re the Hodor plot, sigh.

Euron… @poorquentyn has his theory that there will be a “battle on the astral plane” between Bran and Euron… and while I do get serious Shadow King vibes from Euron (see also), I personally can’t put this speculation in the “definite” or even “slightly certain” category yet. It’s possible. It also might be completely off-base. (I don’t think Euron is a greenseer, I think his dreamwalking is via a glass candle, in which case it might be Sam involved in that plot point more than Bran. Or maybe there’s another glass candle somewhere (the Nightfort?) and it’ll be someone else fighting. Think Aragorn with the palantir, think the climax of The Wizard in Waiting.) We’ll see.

But yeah, once all these terrible things happen in TWOW (maybe the start of ADOS as well), I can see a part of ADOS with Bran pulling back, saying no, Spider-Man no more, and denying his powers. Right when the world really needs him, too. Same with Dany after her own dark night, probably with whatever happens to Jon also… heck I could see Arya, after putting her mother to rest, sinking into depression as well… And then something will happen to make them hope again, to unite for the War for the Dawn, for the last great battle.

And Bran’s big fear will be (if he’s the battle commander / “Ender Wiggin” as @joannalannister theorizes) that he’ll push the others too hard, that they’ll break as Hodor may have… his power and responsibility, fighting to find a balance even as he fights to keep his focus and keep the others focused… mmmnn… all kinds of possibilities here. And a long way off, sigh. Well, we can only wait and see…

blog.description: Bisexual teenage girl with an unhealthy obssesion revolving around tv shows, comic books, books, movies, celebreties, history and superheros, I'm a jack of all obssesions...

body:
Game of thrones

As I’m rewatching the first two seasons I realized something:

When a lord is giving away their castle to someone either because they have an army ready to destroy them or another reason they say “I yield [ _ ] to [ _ ]” . Which is exactly what Bran says to Theon in 2x06. “I yield winterfell to Theon”

However when a lord or lady is welcoming a royal into their home and recognizing their sovereignty they say: “ [ _ ] is yours, your grace”. As we see when King Robert goes to Winterfell and Ned tells him “Your grace, Winterfell is yours.”

This line is also said in season 8 by Sansa to Daenerys. This does not mean that Sansa is giving away Winterfell to Daenerys, just like Ned didn’t give Winterfell to Robert, but simply recognized the king’s power over him.

So everyone calm your tits…

title: Stop hating on Dany 2019
body: Question, Why does Daenerys get shit for burning her enemies? She’s not burning innocent people for pleasure, she’s killing her enemies.  Just like countless of other people do in Game of Thrones. Would people accept it if she beheaded her enemies like Jon, or set hounds on them like Sansa. Dany is using her weapon which just so happens to be a dragon. If she started burning innocent people like Cersei did with the wildfire I would be concerned. But she isn’t. Just another example of Dany getting critiqued for no reason.

summary:
Maester Luwin: Take a lesson, Bran. The man who trusts in spells is dueling with a glass sword.
Bran: Yeah, dragonglass....
body:
Maester Luwin: Take a lesson, Bran. The man who trusts in spells is dueling with a glass sword.
Bran: Yeah, dragonglass. 
Rickon: Burrrrnnnn

dialogue.name: Maester Luwin
dialogue.label: Maester Luwin:
dialogue.phrase: Take a lesson, Bran. The man who trusts in spells is dueling with a glass sword.
